<math alttext="N H 3 aqueous plus H 2 O liquid is in equilibrium with N H 4 with a positive 1 charge aqueous plus O H with a negative 1 charge aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O(</mtext><mi>l</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mo>⇄</mo><msup><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>OH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> <math> <semantics> <mrow> <msub> <mi>K</mi> <mi>b</mi> </msub> <mo>=</mo> <mn>1.8</mn> <mo>×</mo> <msup> <mrow> <mn>10</mn> </mrow> <mrow> <mo>−</mo> <mn>5</mn> </mrow> </msup> <mtext> at 25</mtext> <mo>°</mo> <mtext>C</mtext> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaahqart1ev3aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLn hiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr 4rNCHbGeaGqiFC0pg9uqGrpepeea0dXdHaVhbbe9u8qqaqFr0xc9pk 0xj9qqaqFj0dh9qq=xfr=JarFfpeea0=as0=fs0di9uqFr0=vr0=vr 0db8meaabaqaciGacaGaaeqabaWaaeaaeaaakeaacaWGlbWaaSbaaS qaaiaadkgaaeqaaOGaeyypa0JaaGymaiaac6cacaaI4aGaey41aqRa aGymaiaaicdadaahaaWcbeqaaiabgkHiTiaaiwdaaaGccaqGGaGaae yyaiaabshacaqGGaGaaeOmaiaabwdacqGHWcaScaqGdbaaaa@4ACB@ </annotation> </semantics> </math>

<math alttext="N H 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> is a weak base that reacts with water according to the chemical equilibrium represented above. The table provides some information for two <math alttext="N H 3 aqueous " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> solutions of different concentration at <math alttext="25 degrees Celsius " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>25</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Which of the following is true about the more concentrated <math alttext="0.30 molar N H 3 aqueous " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.30</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>NH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>, and why?

choices.label: <math alttext="the molar concentration of O H with a negative 1 charge equals 3.2 times 10 to the negative 3 power molar" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>[</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>OH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>]</mtext><mo>=</mo><mn>3.2</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></msup><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="p O H is less than 2.78" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pOH</mtext><mo><</mo><mn>2.78</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, because a higher <math alttext="the molar concentration of O H with a negative 1 charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>[</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>OH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo>]</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> corresponds to a lower <math alttext="p O H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pOH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> for <math alttext="0.30 molar N H 3 aqueous " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.30</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>NH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> compared to <math alttext="0.15 molar N H 3 aqueous " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.15</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>NH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>.

<math alttext="the molar concentration of O H with a negative 1 charge equals 3.2 times 10 to the negative 3 power molar" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>[</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>OH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>]</mtext><mo>=</mo><mn>3.2</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></msup><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="p O H is greater than 2.78" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pOH</mtext><mo>></mo><mn>2.78</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, because a higher <math alttext="the molar concentration of O H with a negative 1 charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>[</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>OH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo>]</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> corresponds to a higher <math alttext="p O H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pOH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> for <math alttext="0.30 molar N H 3 aqueous " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.30</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>NH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> compared to <math alttext="0.15 molar N H 3 aqueous " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.15</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>NH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>.

skill.text: 5.C: Explain the relationship between variables within an equation when one variable changes.
